hits.title: Apple’s Mac event has Chinese fans thinking about buying a Surface
hits.content:
Apple's Mac event last week didn't look great in comparison with Microsoft's surprisingly great event the day before. On Friday I wrote that Microsoft is the new Apple, and it seems like China's tech community may be thinking the same thing. Apple's upgraded MacBook Pro line obviously made headlines across all of China's tech news sites, but commenters seem decidedly underwhelmed by Apple's innovations this go-round. For example, one popular comment on Sina Tech reads:
Apple's launch events are getting more and more disappointing. Originally I was thinking I'd wait for the upgraded MacBook Pro, but it turns out all they "upgraded" was the price. It's just not worth it. Can Apple get back to the transformative way it was in the Steve Jobs era? Now it seems its attempts at change are very stiff. Like the ports. In the Jobs era, everybody was excited by the changes Apple made. If you just keep slowly chewing through your capital, it's just a matter of time before Chinese machines surpass you guys [at Apple].
But if Chinese machines are on the verge of surpassing Apple, it seems for some commenters Microsoft's machines already have. One of the most popular comments on Sina Tech reads: "Compared to the Surface Book, this is totally unattractive." And over on Netease Tech, when one commenter listed some upsides of the new MacBook Pro, another commenter replied: "I think those upsides you mentioned are all even better on the Surface." That reply received five times as many upvotes as the MacBook-praising comment it was responding to. "With the pricing so similar, I choose the Surface," wrote another commenter. Of course, there were also numerous comments across all of China's tech sites praising Apple's newest machines, but the overall mood was decidedly negative. In a Sina Tech poll asking users whether they wanted to buy the new MacBook Pro, only 14.3 percent (as of this writing) said yes. 49.3 percent said they wouldn't buy it, and the other 36.3 percent were undecided. It would be foolish to draw any hard conclusions based on such a limited sample of customer sentiment, but the mood of China's tech site commenters also shouldn't be ignored. After all, commenters were also pretty negative after Apple's iPhone 7 launch, and a month later, analysts were saying China had only "tepid" interest in the new phone. If the same proves true for these new MacBooks, Apple could be in for yet another quarter of scary drops in its China market. And after Microsoft's impressive event last week, it looks likely that Apple loss could end up being Microsoft's gain.
hits.excerpt: Apple's latest Mac launch was so underwhelming that in China, it has fans thinking about the Microsoft Surface.

hits.title: Apple buys its first Indian startup
hits.content:
Apple has bought Tuplejump, a Hyderabad-based startup that uses artificial intelligence to understand and manage big data, according to reports from TechCrunch and Bloomberg. The acquisition happened in June, Bloomberg said. Tuplejump was founded by Rohit Rai, Satyaprakash Buddhavarapu, and Deepak Alur. According to Rohit and Satyaprakash’s LinkedIn profiles, they moved to work at Apple in May. Deepak left to join Anaplan in April. Tuplejump’s site has been taken down. “Apple buys smaller technology companies from time to time, and we generally do not discuss our purpose or plans,” Colin Johnson, an Apple spokesman, said in a statement to TechCrunch. If the reports are true, this will be Apple’s third acquisition this year. Last month, it bought machine-learning startup Turi for US$200 million. In January, it bought Emotient for an undisclosed amount. Emotient uses artificial intelligence to analyze facial expressions to figure out emotions. It's also yet another addition to the company's foray into artificial intelligence technology. In October 2015, Apple acquired Perceptio, which makes it possible to run artifical intelligence image-classification programs on phones without needing too much customer data. Tuplejump will be the first Indian startup that Apple has bought. The southern city of Hyderabad has had some of its other startups get attention. AppVirality, a startup that develops toolkits to help mobile developers figure out how to grow their apps, has been backed by Rajan Anandan, managing director of Google India and Southeast Asia. Source: TechCrunch

See: AI is the recurring theme in Microsoft Accelerator's latest batch of startups

hits.title: Apple’s jet black iPhone 7 is its cheapest trick yet
hits.content:
When Apple's new iPhone 7 phones went on sale last week, they went on sale with a new color: jet black. In its launch video, Apple laid the marketing on pretty thick; designer Jony Ive says the black is the result of a "whole new process" that produces "the most singular, most evolved" iPhone ever. With all due respect to Mr. Ive, I disagree. Apple's jet black iPhone isn't singular. It's derivative, it's user-unfriendly, and it's a pretty transparent cash-grab.

This isn't even new!

First of all, does no one remember that early iPhones, including the first iPhone ever, the iPhone 3G came with a glossy black finish? I'm not sure whether or not those phones went through "rotational 3D polishing" with a "specialized compound" or "a magentized ultra-fine ion particle bath" like Ive gushed about with the iPhone 7. But the end result is pretty much the same. It's a shiny black iPhone. Remind me again why I'm supposed to be drooling over a color I had on an iPhone back in 2008?

Fingerprint magnet

Of course, there is a good reason glossy black hasn't been available on iPhones since the early days. That glossy mirror-black that looks so great in promotional photos looks pretty terrible in real life when the phone's being handled by a human. The shiny finish collects smudges and fingerprints, and the black color helps them stand out. The end result is that after a few days of real use, the old gloss-black iPhones generally had back covers that looked like they'd been worked over by a sticky-fingered toddler. And despite all of the complex jargon Ive used to describe the iPhone 7's "new" jet black finish, it shares the exact same problem as older black gloss finishes. Don't take my word for it; here's Wired on the new jet black phones:
Most of [jet black iPhone 7 buyers] will admire their super shiny phone exactly once, because, as reviewers have noted, that lust-worthy luster turns into a serious smudgefest within minutes. Like, way worse than the not-jet-black black. Turns out, the same properties that make for superior sheen also attract fingerprints faster than a season of CSI: Miami.
Whoops. And of course, glossy finishes tend to show scrapes and scratches more conspicuously too.

Xiaomi-style sales tactics

So, you've got a not-really-new color that actually looks worse than any other iPhone color as soon as people put their hands on the phone. How do you sell that? You hype the crap out of it and then tell people supplies are limited. In Apple's defense, as a business tactic this works well. It certainly worked for Xiaomi in the early days. And given that jet black phones are mostly sold out across the globe, it's obviously working for Apple, too. It's not very consumer-friendly, though, because it encourages phone-scalping. And at least in China (Apple's biggest market) it seems like things are already getting out of hand; Chinese media has reported scalpers charging as much as US$3,000 for jet black iPhones, having bought up all the supply themselves. Apple could have prevented this. Given that the phone's physical design is so similar to previous versions, it's very difficult to believe that time or technical limitations could have prevented Apple from producing more jet black phones if it had wanted to. And Apple certainly could (and should) have guessed that scalpers would be all over the jet black models given how much Apple hyped them during the launch event. But of course, Apple didn't want to prevent this, because news of the jet black phones being sold out is great marketing that makes the new phones seem desirable and more likely to sell better in the long run. We can't blame Apple too much for trying to make money. But that doesn't mean we need to buy into this cheap trick. Buy whatever phone you want, but don't be fooled by the hype of jet black. And whatever you do, don't pay scalper prices for a phone that (I'd be willing to bet) will be available on a broad scale at list price within a few months.
hits.excerpt: Buy the iPhone 7 if you like, but don't buy the jet black version.

hits.title: Apple’s ‘courageous’ headphone change is actually anything but
hits.content:
If today's press event is any indication, there's one word that Apple wants associated with its controversial ditching of the headphone jack in the new iPhone 7: courageous. Apple senior VP Phil Schiller made it explicit during the event: "I'm going to give you three [reasons we removed the headphone jack], but it really comes down to one word: courage. The courage to move on, do something new that betters all of us. And our team has tremendous courage." This isn't courage, though. Apple's move to eliminate the headphone jack could have been courageous, but the company didn't go far enough. As it stands, the lightning headphone jack isn't courageous, it's just a crass money-grab.

What is, and what could have been

To be clear, Apple has some genuinely good reasons for removing the old headphone jack. In principle, the lightning jack is just better. It takes up less space, and because it can send power as well as audio, it allows for some cool plug-in devices that won't need external power (like the batteryless noise-cancelling JBL headphones Apple showed off at its event). But there are, of course, two main problems with removing the headphone jack as Apple has:
  1. Using any older headphones now requires you to carry around an adapter. There's no way around it, this is inconvenient, and the entire point of having a mobile phone is to carry less stuff around, not more.
  2. You can no longer use headphones while charging. As numerous people have pointed out, this breaks lots of people's habits and workflows.
Apple's answer to the first problem is pretty simple: deal with it or buy new headphones. This makes sense since Apple owns a headphone company. But it also makes sense because "buy new headphones" is also Apple's answer to the second problem. You can listen with headphones while charging your phone if you grab a pricey new pair of Beats or Apple's newly-announced Airpod earbuds. The Airpods were presented at today's event as Apple's vision of the future. This, Apple said, is how things will look in the wireless world we're building by killing off the headphone jack. Oh, and by the way, these'll cost you an extra US$160. (Sure, you could use a cheap pair of bluetooth headphones, but those won't magically auto-connect the way the Apple ones do. Plus, I doubt Apple's vision of the future entails you having to buy some other company's product to fully enjoy theirs).

Cowards!

That price is where Apple's courage apparently failed. The company took away the iPhone's headphone jack and said "Look, we have the courage to make this futuristic wireless-first phone." But Cook and company didn't really have the courage to present consumers with that vision. They didn't want to walk all the way out onto that limb. So instead, the iPhone 7 comes with an adapter and a pair of wired earbuds that'll be useless whenever your phone is charging. If you want a taste of the future, that'll cost you an extra US$160. You know what real courage would have been? Throwing in those wireless Airpods for free. Doing that would have been a huge risk. It would hurt Apple's profitability in the short term. That, in turn, would probably knock the company's stock price down. Corporate suits would say it's not a good idea, even if the company could afford it (which it clearly could; the iPhone has ridiculous margins and Apple has ridiculously huge cash reserves anyway). But it would have been great. It would have been Apple saying "Here's our new idea, we want to sell everyone on it. Because with the iPhone 7, wireless isn't an upgrade, it's the core experience." That would have been courageous. That would have been the kind of "revolutionary" move that Apple was once famous for. Of course, Apple didn't do that. Instead we got more of what Apple's been providing lately: weak sauce. Half measures. If you buy an iPhone 7 or 7 Plus, you won't actually get to experience Apple's wireless vision unless you pony up and buy another overpriced product on top of that. And without the wireless headphone experience, the single-lightning-port iPhone is just straight-up inferior to basically every other phone out there. I mean, say what you will about the "totally redesigned" home button (which is still a circular button that does all the same things). But even my old iPhone 3G would let me charge it up while watching Netflix. I was never a huge fan of Steve Jobs, nor do I believe that he's responsible for as much of Apple's success as he's often given credit for. But I think the company sorely missed him on the iPhone 7. Because whatever else you could say about Jobs, no one would deny that when he had a vision he stuck to it. Stubbornly. Unflinchingly. I think Jobs would have embraced the iPhone 7's vision of a default-wireless audio experience, even at the cost of making old headphones incompatible. But shipping a product where users (by default) couldn't experience that wireless audio vision? I can't imagine Jobs would have been on board with that. Apple's vision of a wireless-headphone world? That's courageous (although not very original). It's just a shame that instead of giving that vision to us with the iPhone 7, Apple decided it would rather hawk extra headphones on the side.

hits.title: Apple’s new iPhone 7 is coming; here are the launch dates for Asia
hits.content:
Apple has officially unveiled its new iPhone 7 and iPhone 7 Plus models. You probably know all about them already, but just in case you don't, here's are the basics: The new phones are waterproof (IP67), so you can stop worrying about spills. Apple has also removed the old headphone jack and left only the lightning port, so you can also stop worrying about charging your phone and using headphones at the same time, too. Unless you buy the expensive new wireless Airpods separately, of course. The new phones sport an upgraded camera (the 7 Plus even has a dual-lens camera) with optical image stabilization. Then there are the more predictable updates: the display is brighter, the chip is faster, the speakers are louder (and stereo!), etc. The phones will cost exactly what you'd expect: US$649 for the smaller iPhone 7, and US$769 for the larger iPhone 7 Plus. But thankfully, finally, Apple has done away with the 16 GB option, so each phone is now available with a default storage of 32 GB, with available upgrades to 128 and 256 GB.

Asia release details

China, Japan, Singapore, Taiwan, and Hong Kong, will get the new iPhones on the same timeline as the US: orders open this Friday (Sept. 9), and the phones start shipping on the 16th. Everyone else, unfortunately, gets to wait a little bit, as Apple didn't announce a specific release date for any other Asian countries during the event. Additionally, Apple announced that fans in China can now join Apple's iPhone subscription program, in which users can pay a monthly fee to be eligible for a new iPhone every year. Previously, that was only available to customers in the US. Apple also launched a new version of its Apple Watch, but did not announce any Asia-specific launch dates.

hits.title: Apple announces Apple Watch Series 2, making its older watch obsolete
hits.content: At its press event in California today, Apple announced the news that original Apple Watch owners were probably dreading: they've made a new Apple Watch. And it's way better. The new watch, which Apple is calling the Watch Series 2, boasts some pretty serious upgrades over its predecessor, especially if you're a fitness buff. It's waterproof to 50 meters, and it now has a built-in GPS so that it can track activities like runs and hikes without needing to be paired with an iPhone. It also sports a new display that gets up to a ridiculous 1,000 nits of brightness - the brightest display Apple has ever put on any product - so that you can still read it easily outside on a sunny day. There's even a special version Apple has created specifically for runners in partnership with Nike's Nike Plus. There are also some basic upgrades. Among them: a new dual core processor that should make the watch a bit snappier. The new series 2 watch starts at US$369, and you can preorder it on September 9. It goes on sale in the US on September 16, but Apple didn't share any details about the release dates for other regions. Apple is also upgrading its old watch with the new dual core processor, so if you want one of those but aren't interested in the other upgrades (like onboard GPS and waterproofing), you can still buy the older "series 1" starting at US$269.

title.value: Apple announces Apple Watch Series 2, making its older watch obsolete

content.value: At its press event in California today, Apple announced the news that original Apple Watch owners were probably dreading: they've made a new Apple Watch. And it's way better. The new watch, which Apple is calling the Watch Series 2, boasts some pretty serious upgrades over its predecessor, especially if you're a fitness buff. It's waterproof to 50 meters, and it now has a built-in GPS so that it can track activities like runs and hikes without needing to be paired with an iPhone. It also sports a new display that gets up to a ridiculous 1,000 nits of brightness - the brightest display Apple has ever put on any product - so that you can still read it easily outside on a sunny day. There's even a special version Apple has created specifically for runners in partnership with Nike's Nike Plus. There are also some basic upgrades. Among them: a new dual core processor that should make the watch a bit snappier. The new series 2 watch starts at US$369, and you can preorder it on September 9. It goes on sale in the US on September 16, but Apple didn't share any details about the release dates for other regions. Apple is also upgrading its old watch with the new dual core processor, so if you want one of those but aren't interested in the other upgrades (like onboard GPS and waterproofing), you can still buy the older "series 1" starting at US$269.

hits.title: Apple surpassed by Xiaomi, Huawei in China as iPhone market share falls
hits.content: Apple itself admits that it didn't have the greatest quarter ever in Q2 when it comes to China. Now, a report from market research firm Kantar Worldpanel ComTech confirms just how bad it was. According to Kantar, the iPhone's China market share has dropped to 17.9 percent, putting it behind domestic competitors Huawei and Xiaomi. Specifically, Kantar says that Huawei now has 25.7 percent of China's mobile market, while Xiaomi controls 18.5 percent of it. Apple's 17.9 percent is down 1.8 percent year-on-year; the company controlled nearly 20 percent of the market at this time last year. Apple's iPhone 6s and 6s Plus are still the top-selling smartphone models in China, according to Kantar. But domestic handsets like the Huawei Mate 8, Huawei P9, Xiaomi RedMi Note 3, Xiaomi Mi 5, and Oppo R9 are increasingly giving Apple a run for its money. The saving grace for Apple in China might be strong demand for its budget-priced iPhone SE - supply constraints prevented that model from making a bigger sales dent, so if the phone becomes more readily available in Q3 its sales should see an uptick. Also, Apple will announce and launch its new iPhone 7 models in the third quarter. New models typically help drive sales up, so Apple's dip below Xiaomi could be just a temporary setback. Kantar's numbers also show a drop in iPhone market share in Japan, from 42.2 percent of the market a year ago down to 38 percent this year. Although the iPhone still holds a larger chunk of the market in Japan than anywhere else Kantar surveyed (including the US), the year-on-year drop of 4.2 percent was also the worst in any region.

hits.title: Apple Music streams into Israel and Korea ahead of Spotify
hits.content:
Apple Music's global expansion continues this week as it arrives in Israel and South Korea. Arch-rival Spotify is not yet available in either country. First launched June 2015, Apple Music, a paid streaming service that comes with a three-month free trial, is up against the likes of Spotify, Deezer, Tidal, Google Play Music, and an array of regional or country-specific rivals. Apple Insider, which spotted both of the latest roll-outs, explains:
For customers in Korea, individual memberships come in at $7.99 per month or $11.99 for families of up to six people.
While in Israel, it's cheaper:
In Israel, Apple Music is priced at 19.90 Israel Shekels (about $5.20) per month for an individual plan or 29.90 ISL [$7.80] for a family plan of up to six users. The cost is well below US price tiers, likely due to content licensing negotiations, but roughly equivalent to other international markets.

hits.title: Apple’s China revenue dropped off a cliff this quarter
hits.content:
Apple's revenue numbers for what it calls Q3 2016 are in, and there's only one word for how the company did in China: ouch. For this quarter, Apple reported US$8.85 billion in greater China (including Taiwan and Hong Kong) revenues. That's a massive 33 percent drop year-on-year (Apple reported US$13.23 billion in greater China revenue in Q3 2015), and a 29 percent drop from last quarter. Last quarter was record-breakingly bad for Apple, so a further drop isn't exactly good news.

This is the global overview of Apples revenues since 2013 for the five main geographies that it uses in its breakdown. Europe has edged past greater China to regain the number two spot:

And this is how it looks with the greater China region on its own:

Downer

Apple did get some good Asia news out of Japan. Japan revenues are actually up almost 23 percent year-on-year to US$3.53 billion. But the rest of Asia let the Cupertino company down, falling to US$2.38 billion - a 19.5 percent drop year-on-year. Apple's total revenues from across Asia add up to US$14.75 billion, a 22 percent year-on-year drop. iPhone, iPad, and Mac unit sales numbers all dropped year-on-year as well, and again it was the iPhone that had the biggest slump, with unit sales dropping 15 percent year-on-year. Before last quarter, iPhone sales had never dropped year-on-year and total revenue hadn't dropped since 2003. Now, both of those things have happened for two quarters in a row, and according to Apple's Q4 guidance, investors should expect another year-on-year drop in Q4. If there's a silver lining for Apple, it's that these results are actually less bad than investors initially anticipated. In fact, Apple's stock actually jumped five points in after-hours trading following the release. Also, the company's services business - which Apple expects to play an increasingly important role - grew 19 percent year-on-year, although it still accounts for less than 15 percent of the company's total revenue.

India stronger

In the company's earnings call, Apple CEO Tim Cook stressed (as he did last quarter) that 2015 was a particularly strong year of revenue growth for Apple, which makes living up to that standard difficult. But he highlighted some additional areas the company sees as promising: the iPhone SE is doing well in emerging markets and bringing new customers onboard. And the Apple Watch remains the best-selling smartphone in the world (although there isn't much competition). Both Tim Cook and Apple CFO Luca Maestri said that the company saw strong results in India, although they haven't yet shared specific numbers. During the Q&A portion of the call, Cook was asked about Apple's investment in Chinese ride-hailing company Didi, and said that the connection to Didi will help Apple learn about the Chinese market. He said Apple will make similar investments in the future, although big cash splashes won't be a regular occurrence. Cook was also asked about China's recent ban on Apple Books and Apple Movies, but he sort of dodged the question, saying that the financial impact of the ban was minimal. That's doubtless true, but it may still trouble investors that Apple services business - which the company is touting as an important part of its future - is running into these sorts of regulatory roadblocks in one of the company's most important markets. (UPDATED eight hours after publishing: Added in the two charts and the Tim Cook photo.)

hits.title: Apple drops to 5th place in China’s smartphone market
hits.content:
Yikes. We already knew Apple had a historically bad time last quarter, and it seems things haven't improved much in the months since. According to a new report from market research firm Counterpoint Research, Apple has dropped into fifth place in China's smartphone market. Via Bloomberg:
Apple Inc. dropped to fifth place in Chinese smartphone shipments, losing ground in its biggest overseas market in a fresh blow for the technology giant. IPhones made up 10.8 percent of devices sold in May, down from 12 percent a year earlier, according to Counterpoint Research. By comparison, Chinese vendor Huawei Technologies Co. increased its lead with 17.3 percent. [...] Local brands Huawei, Vivo, Oppo and Xiaomi are now the top four smartphone makers in China with a combined market share of 53 percent, according to Counterpoint research director Neil Shah. Oppo almost doubled its market share to 11 percent.
Apple had better hope that its forthcoming iPhone 7 inspires Chinese smartphone buyers to whip out their wallets again. If it doesn't, the company could be facing something nearly unprecedented: a drop out of China's top five smartphone brands.
hits.excerpt: Apple is on the verge of crashing out of China's top five thanks to stiff local competition.

hits.title: Apple’s investment in Didi is more than meets the eye
hits.content:
Earlier in May, Apple joined in the sharing economy with its US$1b investment in China’s largest ride-sharing service, Didi Chuxing. Ride-sharing marketplaces like Didi have been disrupting the traditional transportation economy, bringing the future of car ownership and public transport into question. What does Apple’s move mean for the sharing economy? Apple, traditionally a smartphone provider, is slowly shifting towards being a services provider. Apple Pay, Music and CarPlay are some of the services it has started to offer since the turn of the decade. However, its investment in Didi marks its first foray into the on-demand economy, entering the company into unchartered waters. Apart from the increase in funding, we take a look at how the sharing economy will be affected by the investment.

China will lead the way for the sharing economy

Despite the global economic slump, Didi has been experiencing exceptional growth since its inception in February 2015, with its valuation soaring from $6 billion to the $25 billion today. It dominates the ride-sharing market in China, beating out global giant Uber and completing 11 million rides daily (furthermore, this translates into 1 percent market penetration, leaving much room for expansion). Didi has been able to make use of a relative freedom in the Chinese market, as China aims to shift its economic focus towards higher-value services such as the technology Didi operates with. On the contrary, Uber has been embroiled in regulatory and legal issues in its home country, most recently fleeing Austin to avoid regulations, including fingerprint background checks on its drivers. China looks increasingly promising as the key driver for the sharing economy in the future.

The sharing economy is a data treasure trove

With on-demand services like Didi and Uber, cars can be summoned with a mobile app instantly to your location. Ride-sharing services are able to answer the question, “How many cars do we need if cars were to be shared” with such precision due to the vast amounts of data that they collect in the marketplace. It enabled Didi to scale with this creation of data, analysing it to solve customers’ needs. The data collected from its 1.43 billion rides in 2015 could even be used to anticipate traffic congestion and re-direct its drivers on the most efficient routes. Speaking in an interview, Apple CEO Tim Cook identified that the investment was “for a number of strategic reasons, including a chance to learn more about certain segments of the China market.” Apple’s investment in Didi enables it to leverage on its data to optimize store locations based on the data collected from 300 million users in more than 400 cities.

Marketplaces in the sharing economy

In essence, a marketplace is a platform that aggregates masses of buyers and sellers together. The success of a marketplace predicates on the scale that it builds and the resulting network effects that comes with it. Apple’s investment could allow it to latch onto these effects, allowing it to integrate its services such as CarPlay or iTunes into a larger audience. Marketplaces link the sharing economy together; serving as the meeting place for riders and drivers. With Apple’s investment, the benefits will only get better. Increased synchronization of Didi’s marketplace with the Apple ecosystem can improve the user experience, simplifying the ride-hailing process even further. This would further boost the iPhone’s 27 percent market share in the Chinese market. For drivers, this provides a new opportunity to utilize their idle assets, or even spare time in the summer to earn an extra side income, especially with the large subsidies that Didi reportedly offers for its drivers.

In conclusion

Somewhere in the (near) future, in China, a passenger asks Siri to hail an Apple-provided self-driving car via Didi Chuxing, taking him to the latest Apple store that opened in the city. With Apple’s latest investment, this scenario seems likelier than ever. People stand to gain from the increased precision of predictability gathered from deep data analyses. It could lead to increased efficiency in the transport industry. At the base of it all lies a marketplace, a platform that links riders and drivers, allowing people to breathe life into their idle assets and earn extra cash.

hits.title: Apple hits goal of 40 stores in China
hits.content: In 2010, with Steve Jobs at the helm, Apple vowed to open 25 new stores in China over the next two years. But it never happened. Tim Cook renewed the promise back in late 2014 - and this month we see the company has hit the target ahead of schedule. Apple has just announced two new stores in China that will launch in the next couple of weeks. Those bring the tally of Apple Stores in China to 40, up from 15 when Cook said the expansion would start. There are now 36 in the mainland plus four in Hong Kong. As noticed by Apple Insider, the two newest stores are in Shanghai (the sixth in the city) and Tianjin (its second one). Apple's fulfilling its China promise may have more to do with its retail boss, Angela Ahrendts, than with the CEO. Ahrendts joined Apple in early 2014, leaving her post as Burberry CEO to rejuvenate the official Apple Stores and speed up their global expansion. Apple's most recent quarterly financials may have been the company’s worst in more than a decade, but the huge popularity of the iPhone in China, particularly since the iPhone 6 came out in 2014, has created a huge surge in revenue from the country. The "greater China" area - the mainland, Hong Kong, Macau, and Taiwan all grouped together - accounted for nearly double the revenue of Japan and the rest of the entire Asia-Pacific area combined at its peak at the end of 2015. Despite the ups and downs, Apple's China revenue is trending upwards - and the company sees its own official stores in major cities as an important part of the strategy to win over the country's large middle class. A radically refreshed iPhone 7 could see Apple hit new highs in China towards the end of the year. See: Apple invests $1 billion in Chinese ride-hailing app Didi

hits.title: Apple Pay now available to customers of 5 major banks in Singapore
hits.content:
Apple Pay is finally making its big move towards becoming ubiquitous in Singapore. As Channel NewsAsia reports:
Tech giant Apple announced the expansion of its mobile payment service, Apple Pay, in the Republic on Wednesday (May 25). Before this, only customers with cards issued directly by American Express were able to use the service. It is now available to customers of DBS, OCBC, Standard Chartered and UOB. That translates to about 83 per cent of credit and debit cards in the country.
Singapore's high credit card penetration of 78 percent was cited by Apple as the reason it's the first market in Asia (outside of China) to get the service. Apple isn't the only company making a mobile payments play in Singapore. The country's biggest telco SingTel has Dash, which also uses NFC technology to make payments. Samsung Pay is set to launch in the country this year, but appears to be a step slow. EZ-Link cards, ubiquitous in Singapore as a means of paying for bus and train rides, can also be used to pay for goods at some stores.

hits.title: Apple to launch design and development accelerator in India
hits.content:
Apple will open an iOS App Design and Development Accelerator in Bangalore, India, early next year, the company announced today. The accelerator will provide specialized support for iOS developers in India, from design tips to programming guidance. The accelerator will be based in Bangalore, where Microsoft Ventures also runs its accelerator. In February, 500 Startups also launched an India-focused accelerator. This news comes during CEO Tim Cook's first official visit to India.

Betting on local players

“India is home to one of the most vibrant and entrepreneurial iOS development communities in the world,” Cook said in a statement announcing the accelerator. title.value: Apple to launch design and development accelerator in India

content.value:
Apple will open an iOS App Design and Development Accelerator in Bangalore, India, early next year, the company announced today. The accelerator will provide specialized support for iOS developers in India, from design tips to programming guidance. The accelerator will be based in Bangalore, where Microsoft Ventures also runs its accelerator. In February, 500 Startups also launched an India-focused accelerator. This news comes during CEO Tim Cook's first official visit to India.

Betting on local players

“India is home to one of the most vibrant and entrepreneurial iOS development communities in the world,” Cook said in a statement announcing the accelerator. Cook was recently in China, where he also met with local iOS developers. There is no word yet on the funding or staff that will be involved in the accelerator. For some context, Microsoft Ventures' accelerator, which focuses on helping mature startups scale, has hosted 83 startups since it launched last March, and each has pulled in an average funding of US$1.08 million. See: Microsoft Ventures’ latest batch of 12 startups has raised US$18 million Apple's accelerator has already received praise from Zomato CEO Deepinder Goyal and Snapdeal co-founder and CEO Kunal Bahl. The company's statement quotes Deepinder as saying, "This is a huge vote of confidence in India’s developer community and a tremendous opportunity to gain world-class design and development expertise." The accelerator will launch in early 2017.

hits.title: Apple invests $1 billion in Didi Kuaidi
hits.content:
Didi Chuxing - the Chinese ride-hailing company formerly known as Didi Kuaidi - announced today that it has received US$1 billion from Apple, the largest single investment the company has ever received. Apple's investment comes after a rocky few months in China, where it reported a large drop in phone sales and saw two of its web stores censored by the government. CEO Tim Cook earlier announced plans to visit the People's Republic later this month. Initially, this trip was thought to be tied to Apple's sales and the censorship, but we wouldn't be surprised if he swings by Didi's offices as well.

Lots of potential

It is unclear exactly what this new partnership will mean for Didi and Apple. The app's previous investors, such as Tencent and Alibaba, provided obvious advantages for payment systems, social media, and other web services. In a statement released this morning, Tim Cook said that Didi "exemplifies the innovation taking place in the iOS developer community in China," and that the folks at Apple "look forward to supporting them [Didi] as they grow." What this means (ride hailing buttons built into iOS? Sharing user data? Use of Apple Maps for Didi drivers abroad?) is still speculative. This isn't Apple's first foray into the world of transportation. Rumors of an Apple-affiliated electric car have been commonplace in tech circles for years, and recent news suggests that it may be close to release. Didi Chuxing is still in the midst of its current fundraising round. We'll see who else joins in as the round progresses, but one thing is clear - the anti-Uber alliance has some powerful players on its side.
hits.excerpt: Uber's arch-rival in China just got itself a very strong and wealthy friend. Prepare yourself for Uber vs Apple.

hits.title: Apple’s China revenue drops sharply in record-breakingly poor earnings
hits.content:
Analysts expected that when Apple announced its quarterly earnings this morning, it would be the company's worst quarter in more than a decade. Now, the results are in, and they're not pretty. iPhone sales have dropped year-on-year for the first time ever, and revenue dropped for the first time in a decade. And China, which has often been the engine of growth Apple can lean on in the lean times, saw a big drop, too. Apple says that its revenue from the greater China area (China, Hong Kong, Macau, and Taiwan) this quarter totaled US$12.49 billion. That number is down 26 percent year-on-year, and 32 percent compared to last quarter. In the earnings call, Apple VP Luca Maestri stressed that Apple's record-breaking China Q2 last year, in which the company grew 82 percent, is very difficult to live up to.

Here's the global picture:

As you see, the rest of Asia didn't fare much better. The company did chart a 24 percent year-on-year revenue increase in Japan - the only region where Apple's revenues grew year-on-year - and in the earnings call, Tim Cook said that iPhone sales in India climbed 56 percent year-on-year. But those gains were mostly offset by the rest of Asia, where revenue slumped 25 percent. Apple's total sales came in at US$50.4 billion - nothing to sneeze at, but lower than analysts had projected. And its forecasts for next quarter look even worse, with the American tech giant expecting between US$41-43 billion in revenue. In the earnings release, Apple CEO Tim Cook praised his team's performance "in the face of strong macroeconomic headwinds," and emphasized the grown in Apple's services offerings, which were up 20 percent year-on-year. Services are considered an especially important sector for Apple, because if the market for iDevices is as saturated as this quarter's results suggest, Apple will need to find more ways of monetizing its existing users through services like iCloud and Apple Pay.

hits.title: Apple’s iBooks and iTunes Movies gone from China
hits.content:
Apple’s iBooks and iTunes Movies stores are now unavailable to users within China, as the country’s regulators tighten their grip over the media that’s accessible by citizens of the People’s Republic. The stores weren’t censored in the conventional sense. Normally, when we say that China has censored a foreign company’s website or media, it means that internet connections to that site have been blocked - such as Facebook, YouTube, and the like. But in this case, Apple had jumped through all of the government’s hoops, and had gone legit in China. The iBooks and iTunes Movie stores were registered with the State Administration of Press, Publication, Radio, Film, and Television (the unpronounceable SAPPRFT), and had approval to operate in the country - until, suddenly, they didn’t. According to the New York Times, SAPPRFT demanded Apple shut the stores, and reps at Apple are scrambling to get the libraries available again.

Push and pull

Apple’s media offerings in China have always been different from the rest of the world. Its iBooks and Movies stores just launched last September and offered a selection of products specially curated for China. “Curated” means that some items were censored, but it also means that a tremendous number of Chinese-language material was added to both stores. Chinese versions of iTunes U, the App Store, and Apple’s podcasts market are also available in the mainland. The iTunes Music store has never opened in China, but the Apple Music streaming service launched at the same time as iBooks and iTunes Movies did last year. Running any kind of media distribution network in China is a recipe for trouble. Just this week, SAPPRFT cracked down on a viral video star - certainly not a good sign for a foreign company selling books and movies in the strictly-regulated country. Also earlier this week, in an American congressional testimony, Apple’s general counsel said that the company had refused Chinese requests to turn over its source code. Apple’s is in a weird position in China - on one hand, it is big enough to deny government requests for some data and still operate confidently within the country. On the other hand, its media distribution channels are only a snap SAPPRFT decision away from being knocked offline. The iBooks and iTunes Movie stores were reportedly closed down last week, so the blocking is not likely related to the testimony. We may never know why the state abruptly demanded Apple close up the stores. If they come back online soon, we’ll have to see if any specific material is conspicuously unavailable for download.

hits.title: Apple Pay now available in Singapore – but only for American Express users
hits.content: Its coming was foretold back in October 2015, and now it has arrived. Apple and credit card provider American Express announced this morning that Apple Pay is live in Singapore. Members who got their cards directly from American Express can add them to Apple’s online and NFC payment system and start paying their way across the island using their phones. According to Apple, American Express is currently the only way to use Apple Pay in the city-state, although support for local banks DBS and UOB, and for international bank Standard Chartered, is coming soon. Still, that means that most iOwners in Singapore, who aren’t American Express customers, will be miffed this morning. UPDATE, 1:35pm SGT: Visa has also announced it will be supporting Apple Pay in Singapore "soon," although, as with the banks, no exact time frame is provided. For payments at participating stores, the service supports iPhone 6 and 6s, iPhone 6 Plus and 6s Plus, iPhone SE, and Apple Watch. Using the Touch ID fingerprint-scanning function, owners of the abovementioned devices plus iPad Air 2, iPad mini 3, iPad mini 4, and iPad Pro can use Apple Pay to shop online within apps that accept it. Apple Pay is just one facet of Apple’s renewed interest in Singapore and the Asian market, as the company prepares to launch its first Apple Store in Singapore and has been staff-hunting for it.

hits.title: Apple’s recipe for making successful apps
hits.content:
I’ve spent the better part of a decade building award-winning mobile apps for the App Store. Yet I wanted to back up my own observations with advice directly from Apple (which has documents outlining the process of creating successful apps here, here, and here). If you haven’t read the App Store guidelines, stop reading this article and read it here.

Apple does a great job communicating their guidelines in a no-nonsense, cheeky, way. Within those guidelines, and embedded within some of their other communications, are golden nuggets and sage words straight from the horse’s mouth on how to make successful apps.

If you’re looking to make a living off apps, then you should listen up. This is 2016, and there’s no room for amateurs and wantrepreneurs on the App Store. Let’s dissect some of Apple’s advice so you can make apps like a pro.

Tip #1 from Apple

“We have over a million Apps in the App Store. If your App doesn’t do something useful, unique or provide some form of lasting entertainment, or if your app is plain creepy, it may not be accepted.”

Be useful. Solve a problem the user faces with a usable interface. You can be effective at this by taking a solution that exists and making it better, faster, easier, cheaper, safer or funnier. These words all describe value. Often times, a new product may be more than one of these. Consider how you’re making the someone’s life better. Rethink, refresh, redesign, and recreate things. Remix the old, and make the new.

For example, consider the podcast app Overcast. As a product, it’s certainly not the one with the most comprehensive list of features. Instead of trying to fight many battles, it enhances its odds of winning by focusing on a few. One of its unique abilities is one that helps users save time by automatically speeding up and skipping through silence in a podcast.

Considering how podcasts have been around for a decade, and how Overcast for a relatively short time, this slight additional utility still made it an extremely popular app. It does podcasting very well and improves on the experience in a specific way.

Tip #2 from Apple

“Before creating your app, take a look at the apps in your category on the App Store and consider how you can provide an even better user experience.”

Make something unique. This is meant in the context of the App Store. Does what you plan to build exist already? What can you do to differentiate yourself? Do your research.

Conventional methods yield conventional results. Instead of building something old with enhanced efficiency, with this principle you’re going to be building something completely new. You’ll be doing something that hasn’t been done before. Apple says that this is one of the top reasons apps get rejected from the App Store. “If your app doesn’t offer much functionality or content, or only applies to a small niche market, it may not be approved,” Apple wrote on their website.

Tip #3 from Apple

“Apple places a high value on clean, refined, and user-friendly interfaces. Make sure your UI meets these requirements by planning your design carefully and following our design guides and UI Design Dos and Don’ts.”

Apple is notorious for their attention to detail. The original team signed the inside of the Macintosh, even when they knew little to nobody would see it. In an age where your competitors are obsessed over quantity, you will win by paying attention to quality.

When it comes to building apps, our mantra is to “Make it feature worthy.” People should be thrilled at how enjoyable and beautiful it is, and press should want to cover it. These little details like the app icon, UI sounds, and small parts of the user interface add up to make a big difference.

Tip #4 from Apple:

“If your App looks like it was cobbled together in a few days, or you’re trying to get your first practice App into the store to impress your friends, please brace yourself for rejection. We have lots of serious developers who don’t want their quality Apps to be surrounded by amateur hour.”

There are over 1.6 million apps on the App Store. It’s not a playground for hobbyists and amateurs to share their first apps or half-baked beta builds. Many other developers have put in hundreds (thousands!) of hours into crafting their apps before even attempting to get it published. As such, Apple’s role as a gatekeeper is as important as ever.

Spend the time to get it right, the first time. QA your app carefully. Share it with beta testers. Use it yourself. Try it out on older devices. Fix every possible bug you can find before uploading that V1 build, because chances are you’ll still have missed some.

Don’t submit your app until you’re confident that it’s worthy of four or five stars.

Tip #5 from Apple

“Lastly, we love this stuff too, and honor what you do. We’re really trying our best to create the best platform in the world for you to express your talents and make a living too. If it sounds like we’re control freaks, well, maybe it’s because we’re so committed to our users and making sure they have a quality experience with our products. Just like almost all of you are, too.”

Like all other organizations, Apple works in their own interest. Accepting and promoting apps that are useful, differentiated, have an intuitive user interface, glowing user reviews, and press coverage is in their interest. So do them and yourself a favor, and create the best app that you can.

Closing thoughts

This was somewhat of a serious piece (minus the GIFs), and I’d be the last to say you can’t “have fun” as you build for the App Store. Always remember that for each moment you rest on your laurels there are other experienced developers, entrepreneurs, and designers looking to replace the product that you put together. Attention is a zero sum game.

The major lesson here is to create apps that are useful, unique, well-designed, and refined. Make apps that improve peoples lives in small, but meaningful ways.

hits.title: Apple now accept payments through WeChat
hits.content: Add this to the list of things you can do with WeChat: buy Apple gadgets. Tencent's messaging-app-cum-everything-platform announced Wednesday that support for WeChat Pay has been added to Apple's official online stores in China. That means that you can now use WeChat pay for all of your Apple gadget and accessory needs. WeChat Pay isn't the only epayment system Apple accepts, of course. Obviously Apple's buyers can also use Apple Pay, and the Chinese version of Apple's online store also accepts Alipay, Alibaba's epayment platform. China's fragmented online payment market and the relative lack of credit cards means that Chinese users actually have a lot more payment options than most people when it comes to buying Apple's products. Whereas Americans can pay only with PayPal or one of four major credit card providers, Chinese Apple fans can make online payments directly from ten major banks, pay with Visa, Mastercard, Alipay, or WeChat Pay, or even order items for cash-on-delivery.
hits.excerpt: WeChat Pay can now be used within China to pick up all your favorite Apple gadgets online.

hits.title: Apple says it’s using 100% renewable energy in China and Singapore (sorta)
hits.content: At today's Apple event in Cupertino, Lisa Jackson took the stage to talk about the company's environmental efforts, and shared some relatively impressive news. Apple, Jackson said, is 93 percent renewable worldwide in its offices, Apple Stores, and data centers. But in the US, China, and Singapore, Apple is already using 100 percent renewable energy. That has been achieved in part by local, Apple-led renewable energy projects, according to Jackson. Apple has built two 20 megawatt solar farms in Sichuan, for example, that help move the company towards its renewable goals while maintaining the usability of the local farmland for yak farmers. In Singapore, where space is at a premium, Apple has put solar arrays on more than 800 rooftops. "Every time you send an iMessage," Jackson said, "you can feel really good about reducing your impact on the environment." Apple's achievement is certainly impressive, but there is a bit of an asterisk that Jackson didn't share: it only applies to Apple's own facilities, not those of its suppliers and subcontractors. So while all of Apple's stores, offices, and data centers in China are running on renewable energy, the companies manufacturing and shipping its devices around almost certainly are not. That means your iPhone isn't carbon-neutral even though the Apple Store you bought it from is. Still, 100 percent carbon neutral Apple operations in China, Singapore, and the US is a damn good start! Apple also announced a few other environmental efforts, including ongoing forest preservation efforts in China and a new robot named "Liam" that will deconstruct recycled iPhones to recover more of the materials for reuse.
hits.excerpt: Apple has gone carbon neutral in China and Singapore, the company said today, although there's a little bit of a catch.

hits.title: Apple says it never gave source code or backdoors to China
hits.content:
Apple's latest court filings in its ongoing battle with the American government are pretty entertaining in their own right. But they also shed some light on one of the chief criticisms of Apple in its Department of Justice dealings: namely, that it's refusing to bend for the US government but it has already given in to Chinese government demands. While it is true that Apple has made some concessions to the Chinese government, these latest filings make it pretty clear that Apple denies having done anything like what the FBI and the DOJ are asking for in China. From the filings (citations removed for the sake of clarity):
Apple has never built a back door of any kind into iOS, or otherwise made data stored on the iPhone or in iCloud more technically accessible to any country’s government. The government is wrong in asserting that Apple made “special accommodations” for China, as Apple uses the same security protocols everywhere in the world and follows the same standards for responding to law enforcement requests.
Separately, Apple executive Craig Federighi reportedly confirmed in a court declaration that "Apple has also not provided any government with its proprietary iOS source code." Of course, for the company to say anything less than this publicly would be a public relations disaster. But given that these statements were made in the context of heated ongoing legal proceedings, it's clear that Apple intends to stand behind them. So, if you take the company at its word, you've got the answer to a couple of longstanding rumors: no, China doesn't have the iOS source code, and no, China doesn't have a backdoor into iOS.
hits.excerpt: In court filings, Apple states quite clearly that it has never given China special access to an iOS backdoor or iOS source code.

hits.title: Apple’s court victory over the FBI sparks a political debate online in China
hits.content: Apple got some legal help in its battle with the American FBI on Monday. A federal judge in New York ruled that the FBI cannot force Apple to unlock an iPhone because Congress already considered but did not pass legislation that would force companies to unlock their phones. The New York ruling is legally unrelated to Apple's high-profile battle with the FBI over the iPhone of one of the San Bernardino shooters - that case is playing out in California - but it sets a strong precedent that Apple can cite in its favor as the California case moves forward. In China, tech industry watchers and Apple fans have been following the Apple vs. FBI story with significant interest. It has made headlines across China's major tech portals almost every day since Tim Cook's public letter a few weeks ago. Monday's New York ruling also made headlines in China, and it's got commenters talking. For example, a Sina Tech commenter from Liaoning wrote, "I want to know what this would be like if it were in China." That's purely rhetorical, of course. Everybody knows what would happen to Apple if this fight were in China. As another Sina commenter put it: "Not cracking the phone is kind of like secretly participating in crime, and China will definitely not permit criminals to exist, so naturally the phone would be unlocked." That's not really hypothetical; although Apple has never unlocked a phone in this manner for Chinese authorities, it has jumped through all sorts of hoops to keep its products available in the country. It has censored apps, moved data onto state-owned servers, and even submitted to a government "security audit." If China's government were to come to Apple with a request similar to the FBI's, many suspect the company would cave, since the alternative would likely be a wholesale ban on Apple products in China. As the battle in the US plays out, though, a loss for the FBI is increasingly looking like it would mean a big win for Apple and for American soft power in the region. Numerous comments on the Monday ruling story, for example, suggest that commenters are impressed by the American legal system and the fact that the government doesn't (necessarily) get exactly what it wants. "Democracy!" wrote one Sina commenter in Sichuan. "That's real respect for the law," another commenter in Shaanxi added. "Only in America would there be this kind of outcome," opined a Shanghai commenter. "The constitution comes first." Of course there are also those who think the failure to immediately knock over Apple makes the US government look weak. And many commenters are convinced that the public legal battle is actually a front. Apple must, they figure, be collaborating with the FBI behind closed doors, perhaps covering up the fact that the phone has already been unlocked. "Do you really think the FBI can't hack a phone?" wrote another Sina commenter. "Give me a break."
hits.excerpt: Chinese internet users are watching the Apple vs. FBI battle closely, and it's making them ask questions about their own system of government.

hits.title: Apple Pay’s first day in China: thousands of cards added each minute
hits.content: There's been a lot of skepticism about Apple Pay's prospects in Alipay-dominated China. But if Chinese media reports are to be believed, China's Apple users are at least willing to try it out. According to Yicai, after the service finally went live Thursday morning, it was seeing rates of up to 80,000 cards added each minute in China. That certainly sounds like a lot, but we don't have any total card or user numbers, so take it with a grain of salt. And of course, users adding cards is just the first step anyway. What Apple really needs is for users to start paying with the service. But that could be a tough sell, given that other epayment services like Alipay sometimes offer discounts and are accepted at a wider variety of locations (at least for now). Apple Pay does have a few tricks up its sleeve, though. It has partnered with virtually all of China's big banks, and some of them are already offering promotions (like cashback rewards and discounts) to try to get users to adopt Apple's new service. Those promotions are bank-specific, so you'd need to add their card to Apple Pay to take advantage, but it's better than nothing. Whether it will be enough to tempt loyal users away from Alipay and WeChat is an open question, though.
hits.excerpt: Lots of people are adding their Chinese bank cards to Apple Pay. Now, will they actually use it?

hits.title: Apple Pay launches today in China, ready to take on local tech titans
hits.content: Apple launched its mobile payments system Apple Pay in China this morning, leaping in to a heated battle between WeChat and Alibaba's Alipay. Apple CEO Tim Cook took to Weibo this morning to herald the rollout of the service, which will work in stores and on some websites. "Apple Pay launching in China today. Can't wait for you to try it and see how incredibly easy it is to use!" he wrote in English and Chinese. The Apple Pay rollout in China will be faster than in any other country. Whereas Apple has expanded slowly in the US and other markets by making partnerships with individual banks, in China the company has buddied up with UnionPay, the sole domestic bank card organization and interbank network in the country. That means Apple Pay works with most China-issued debit and credit cards, and will be accepted at any store or restaurant that has installed the new breed of NFC-enabled PIN input dongles issued by UnionPay. That gives Apple Pay a huge footprint from day one. In contrast, Apple's new arch-rivals have expanded more slowly because they're going against the monopolistic UnionPay. Tencent's popular chat app WeChat and its baked-in mobile wallet and Alibaba spin-off app Alipay have had to get stores or chains to sign up to use their services and also install a barcode scanner into their cash registers. But after a head start of a couple of years, both WeChat Pay and Alibaba are now widely accepted at stores of all sizes across China, including major chains such as Uniqlo, FamilyMart, and Sam's Club. As my experiment last year showed, it's pretty easy to go entirely cashless in China using a mix of WeChat and Alipay. That leaves little room for Apple, despite the apparent benefit of the UnionPay partnership. The heated battle between WeChat Pay and Alipay across China means that the services are offering discounts at certain stores, with the Chinese tech titans picking up the tab so that their users can get the benefit of a price-cut with their cashless transaction.

hits.title: Apple and India are slowly starting to love each other
hits.content:
Apple saw iPhone sales in India rise a whopping 76 percent in India in the final three months of 2015, the company said overnight. But the company should not be popping the champagne just yet. While Apple posted strong numbers around the world, analysts will likely be unhappy that the iPhone’s era of hypergrowth is mostly over. Except for in India, where it’s just beginning. India’s iPhone sales growth far outpaced China’s - just 20 percent - in the previous quarter, CEO Tim Cook said on a call with analysts. “And as you know, we've been putting increasingly more energy in India. India revenue for us in the first quarter was up 38 percent,” he added. India is lumped in with the “rest of Asia-Pacific” in Apple’s financials. That all major tech companies in the world are spending some serious time wooing Indians is not news anymore. Just ask Google or Facebook. Apple has been a little late to the game, what with its products being exorbitantly priced, and Indians liking to count their pennies. But as of the past few months, the company has doubled down on the market, expanding its distributor base, bringing in easy financing schemes for its phones, and even launching its first TV spot for the Indian buyer.

When in India

Those efforts showed results. Apple does not break down sales for India, but Tarun Pathak, senior analyst for mobile devices and ecosystems at research firm Counterpoint Technology Market Research said the company sold 800,000 iPhones in India during the fourth quarter of 2015, better than ever before. 800,000 is a whole world of improvement over the 500,000 iPhones Apple sold during the same period in 2014. Apple’s 800,000 in India compares with about 20 million iPhone sales in China. While the media calls India the “bright spot” in Apple’s results, the country isn’t going to make any major difference in Apple’s balance sheet in the near future. Counterpoint’s Tarun said the company accounted for less than 2 percent share of the smartphone market in India as of 2015, while market leader Samsung held 25 percent. Samsung makes some smartphones that can be bought for as little as US$90, which gives it a bigger playing field. But Apple still has a fine balancing act to get right in the country. It’s not fighting Android in the country, it’s fighting itself.

They’re still on the 4s

Across the world, Apple lives off an almost cultish following that peaks over new gadget launches. That is the driver of sales for the company. Not so in India. “In India, Apple’s plan is not to sell new phones, it is just to sell iPhones,” Counterpoint’s Tarun explained. Mobile store retailers agree, saying Apple sells more iPhone 4s, 5s and 5c models in India than the pricier new models. An iPhone 6s costs about US$199 for a standard two-year contract in the United States, where the GDP per capita, or the measure of average income per person in a country, is around US$54,600. The phone costs upwards of US$650 in India, where the GDP per capita is US$ 1,580, according to the World Bank. That solves the mystery of slow iPhone 6s and 6s Plus sales in India for the most part, but Apple isn’t daunted. The Cupertino-based company has already applied to the government for permission to open its first store in the country, and has increased the number of distributors in the country from two to five in the past year. Executives at three big electronics retail chains told Tech In Asia the company was pushing for better shelf space in stores, and had allowed distributors much more leeway to set bargain deals with retailers ahead of its 6s launch in the country. “Earlier, it was one price, take it or leave it. Now with Apple distributors it has become more about who can get us the best deal. they are getting much more leeway on that front,” the CEO of a national electronics store told Tech In Asia." None of them wanted to be identified, citing business relations. Apple did not immediately respond to an email seeking comments. Industry sources say the company recognizes that India is too small right now to make any difference to the company’s balance sheet, but the pressure to beef up presence in a country that is set to become the world’s second biggest smartphone market is enormous. Sitting by the sidelines is not something Apple, or any other smartphone company, for that matter, can afford to do. Even if it means changing its business model and belief a bit. “Apple has gone against its own grain in keeping models like the 4s alive in India,” Jaideep Mehta, managing director of IDC South Asia told Tech In Asia. “That points to the fact that it has realized it cannot change the market, so it has played to the market.”
hits.excerpt: India is less than 2 percent of Apple’s global sales, but the iPhone is now taking off after the company shook up its strategy.

hits.title: Apple just had its best quarter ever in China
hits.content: Apple CEO Tim Cook noted during the company's earnings call this morning that China's "economic softness" was becoming evident, but the slowdown apparently didn't hurt Apple much its Q1 2016 financials (which cover a time span most other companies would consider Q4 2015). During the quarter, Apple says its Greater China (mainland China, Hong Kong, and Taiwan; I'm going to just call it "China" for the rest of this article) revenues totaled US$18.37 billion. That's up more than 14 percent year-on-year. That number also beat's Apple's previous China best (US$16.14 billion), making this past quarter Apple's best-ever quarter in terms of China revenues. This quarter's numbers were (unsurprisingly) fueled by the company's highest-ever China iPhone sales totals. China iPhone sales grew 18 percent this quarter, according to Cook, and almost half of the iPhones sold this quarter were to first-time buyers, which suggests Apple hasn't come close to saturating the market. China also saw 27 percent year-on-year growth in Mac sales. Cook said that despite the signs of economic trouble in China, Apple remains optimistic and will not change its investment plans in the country. The company will continue to invest in retail stores, and it plans to have built another 12 (to add to the 28 it already has) in the China region by this summer.
hits.excerpt: Another quarter gone by, another record-breaking four months for Apple in China.

hits.title: Apple is now hiring for its Singapore store
hits.content: Apple is scouting talent for its official Singapore store, slated to open in 2016. The Apple website lists 14 job postings, including Apple store leader, business manager, and business specialist. The tech giant caused a bit of a hoo-ha when a gym and other retailers were vacated to make way for Apple. The store will apparently be located at Knightsbridge, a monolithic retail and hotel space in Orchard Road, Singapore's premium shopping district. This will be its first retail presence in the country. Previously, Apple aficionados had to make do with authorized third-party stores. Having an official store could bring better customer service to Apple customers through its Genius Bars. It could allow Singapore customers to buy the latest products earlier and try out demo units. Are you excited for the launch of the Apple store in Singapore?
hits.excerpt: The official store is slated to launch in Singapore in 2016 in Orchard Road.

hits.title: Apple’s next frontier isn’t China, it’s Southeast Asia
hits.content:
I’m sure by now everyone has seen Apple’s earnings, and the inevitable smattering of articles pointing at how important China is to the world’s most valuable company. But if you’re an investor, this may smell like China’s peak rather than its growth. Although Apple still has room for growth in China, it appears that the smartphone giant is now looking down south to Southeast Asia. Consider the following:
  • Leaked rumors of Apple opening up its own outlet in Singapore
  • Apple is also opening up a subsidiary in Vietnam
  • Apple hiring for a retail build manager in Jakarta
Beyond these first steps into Southeast Asia, let’s consider the numbers. In 2013, Android was leading Southeast Asia over iOS. But this is still true of China also. As Apple has shown, marketshare isn’t the winning strategy for them, it’s positioning. Most smartphone owners, as they realize the importance of the smartphone to their lives, want to move up the chain to the best smartphones, and this is where Apple positions itself successfully. It’s why Apple is killing it in China. By this logic, if we consider that Android has slowly come to dominate Southeast Asia, than it’s only natural for iOS to slowly encroach on this. Southeast Asians are just as status conscious as Chinese people are. And it’s about time Apple opens up in Southeast Asia. It just did in the Middle East, in a region of over 200 million people. Now, here come the Apple Stores for a region of over 600 million people.
hits.excerpt: Apple is likely looking beyond China for new markets to tackle, and the signs are pointing to Southeast Asia.

hits.title: Apple Pay to hit Singapore and Hong Kong in 2016
hits.content: Apple Pay, Apple's much-hyped cashless payment service, will be available in Singapore next year, according to a press release by credit card provider American Express. The company announced that consumers will be able to use Apple Pay with its products in Canada and Australia this year, and in Singapore, Spain, and Hong Kong in 2016. The service is currently only available in the US and the United Kingdom. Obviously Amex's announcement focuses on its own cards, but it's only reasonable to expect that other credit card providers and banks will get in on the action. In any case, Amex says that customers will be able to use their iPhone, iPad, and/or Apple Watch to pay in stores that accept contactless payments and American Express cards. 2016 will be big for Apple in Singapore, if indications about a possible Apple Store opening in the country prove to be true. Source: Channel News Asia Are you eagerly awaiting Apple Pay's arrival in Singapore? Do you think it will catch on here?
hits.excerpt: American Express has announced it will be supporting Apple's payment service in the two markets next year.
